newsitem.title: SPAIN: TENNIS-MOYA LEADS SPAIN TO DAVIS CUP VICTORY OVER GERMANY.
newsitem.headline: TENNIS-MOYA LEADS SPAIN TO DAVIS CUP VICTORY OVER GERMANY.

text.p: Australian Open finalist Carlos Moya overpowered Hendrik Dreekman in straight sets to give Spain an unbeatable 3-1 lead over Germany in their Davis Cup world group first round tie on Sunday.

"I had to put up with a lot of pressure, I was playing at home...and I'd got to the final in the Australia Open, so winning makes me especially happy," said Moya, who ran out a 6-4 6-4 7-5 winner in just over two hours.
Moya broke Dreekman's serve in the opening game of the first set and served out to take the set.
He started the second set in similar fashion but Dreekman broke back immediatelyand saw a lob that would have given him a further break drift centimetres out with the Spaniard stranded.
Moya survived the scare and won the game with a superb backhand crosscourt pass before breaking serve again at 3-3.

Games went with serve in the third set before Moya apeared to suffer an attack of nerves after breaking Dreekman and serving for the match at 5-4. He broke Dreekman again in the 11th game and recovered from love-30 to clinch the match and the tie.

"I was very confident from the start. I never thought I'd lose, even when I let it slip at 5-4 in the third," said Moya, who lost to world number one Pete Sampras in the final of Australian Open last month.
Coach Manolo Santana praised Moya -- whom he described as a "born Davis Cup player" -- in an emotional post-match press conference during which he embraced the Spanish number one.
"There's a special chemistry between the players, the crowd and the coaching staff, and it shows in the way we play," said Santana.
Albert Costa and Marc Goellner were meeting in the final dead rubber.
